Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient has received a new diagnosis for a chronic condition and has many questions about managing it.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from my mom: “How are you, son? Haven’t heard from you this week.” I glance at it, guilt pricking at me. I know she worries, especially since I moved out for residency. I type a quick reply, promising to call later, but before I can hit send, my pager goes off. Room 312—Mr. Patel, newly diagnosed with diabetes, is anxious and waiting for me. I take a deep breath, feeling the weight of both worlds. My parents expect me to stay connected, to reassure them I’m okay. My patient expects me to be present, to explain, to listen. As I walk toward Mr. Patel’s room, my mom’s message lingers in my mind. I want to be a good son, but right now, I have to be a good doctor. The two roles pull at me, each demanding my time, my empathy, my words. I pause outside the door, torn, my phone still in my hand, uncertain which message to answer first.
